pullRequest.body:
- Lemmas about compositions and products of kernels.
- New definition: `prodMkRight`, similar to `prodMkLeft`: takes `Îº : kernel Î± Î²` and turn it into a `kernel (Î± Ã— Î³) Î²`.

From the PFR project.

---

Looks good!
maintainer merge

For discoverability, could you rename that to
```suggestion
lemma comap_map_eq_map_comap (Îº : kernel Î² Î³) {f : Î± â†’ Î²} {g : Î³ â†’ Î´}
```
or
```suggestion
lemma comap_map_comm (Îº : kernel Î² Î³) {f : Î± â†’ Î²} {g : Î³ â†’ Î´}
```

I think it would be more readable (and more obvious that you or a future contributor didn't miss any lemma) if you interleaved `prodMkLeft` and `prodMkRight` lemmas rather than putting all the `prodMkLeft` ones before all the `ProdMkRight` ones. What do you think?
Done! And doing it indeed helped me realize that I had forgotten to add `prodMkRight_zero` :) (now added).

I'm not too sure which order is mathematically more justified, but I would have both expected
* the type to come before the kernel
* `prodMkRight` to have the same argument order as `prodMkLeft`, whatever that order is

So I would have expected
```suggestion
  comap Îº Prod.snd measurable_snd
#align probability_theory.kernel.prod_mk_left ProbabilityTheory.kernel.prodMkLeft

/-- Define a `kernel (Î± Ã— Î³) Î²` from a `kernel Î± Î²` by taking the comap of the projection. -/
def prodMkRight (Î³ : Type*) [MeasurableSpace Î³] (Îº : kernel Î± Î²) : kernel (Î± Ã— Î³) Î² :=
  comap Îº Prod.fst measurable_fst
```
I guess an extra advantage is that you can more easily reason about the partially applied function `kernel Î± Î² â†’ kernel (Î± Ã— Î³) Î²` (but I'm not sure whether that comes up, you will know better)
The idea was that if you add a type to the left, the type argument is to the left of the kernel. And if you add a type to the right, the type argument is to the right.
Example in PFR: `(prodMkRight Îº T') Ã—â‚– (prodMkLeft T Î·)` where `{Îº : kernel T G} {Î· : kernel T' G}`. I thought placing the type to one side or the other helped visually understand what we get.

Yeah, I understand that, but it goes against my expectation that type arguments go before. Even without this consideration, it seems pretty annoying that `prodMkLeft` and `prodMkRight` have different argument orders even though they are "the same operation", eg when writing an API for both you will need to swap the arguments to half the calls because of this.
Since it really does not matter much: switched.

```suggestion
    const Î± Î¼ Ã—â‚– const Î± Î½ = const Î± (Î¼.prod Î½) := by
```
